Scheme 1 Fe-modified Cu/TiO2 catalyst with anti-Pb poisoning performance for the synergistic catalysis of NH3-SCR and CO oxidation Yang-wen Wu Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Conceptualization Zheng-long Wu Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Hai-yuan Zhao Software Methodology Investigation Xu Su Validation Formal analysis Ji-hong Li Writing – review & editing Qiang Lu Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ National Engineering Research Center of New Energy Power Generation, North China Electric Power University, Beijing 102206, PR China National Engineering Research Center of New Energy Power Generation, North China Electric Power University Beijing 102206 PR China National Engineering Research Center of New Energy Power Generation, North China Electric Power University, Beijing 102206, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Nitrogen oxides (NO x ) and carbon monoxide (CO) are two major pollutants in industrial flue gas. Currently, ammonia selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) and CO oxidation catalysts are susceptible to heavy metal impurities such as Pb, which leads to a reduction in catalytic activities. In this study, an excellent anti-Pb poisoning Fe-enhanced Cu/TiO2 catalyst was prepared for the synergistic control of NO and CO with maximum 91.2 % and 99 % conversion ratios at 275 °C. The active components of the modified catalyst were well dispersed on the TiO2. The doping of Fe alleviated the surface aggregation caused by Pb, while the pore size was decreased and the specific surface area was increased. Synergistic interaction between Cu and Fe produced more variable valence states, leading to highly active chemisorbed oxygen and oxygen vacancies, which were beneficial for the NO and CO removal. Furthermore, after Fe loading more acidic sites were retained on the catalyst surface, which improved the oxidation–reduction characteristics of the catalyst. This research presents a viable approach for designing efficient catalyst for the concurrent removal of NO and CO from industrial emissions while demonstrating great resistance to Pb-poisoning. Graphical abstract The process of synergistic removal of NO and CO by Cu-Fe-Pb/Ti catalyst. Image, graphical abstract Keywords NH3-SCR CO oxidation Cu/TiO2 catalyst Fe modified Anti-Pb poisoning Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nitric monoxide (NO), as one of the common atmospheric pollutants, can lead to serious environmental issues including haze, acid precipitation, and ozone layer depletion [1–3]. For the removal of NO, selective catalytic reduction (SCR) technology is the most widely applied for stational industrial flue gas using ammonia (NH3) as the reducing agent [4,5]. Under the action of a catalyst, NH3 converts NO into nitrogen (N2), thereby achieving the goal of reducing NO emissions [6–8]. However, in some industrial exhausts such as the sintering flue gas in iron and steel industry, the emission of NO is always accompanied by a large amount of carbon monoxide (CO) [9–11]. To achieve the simultaneous removal of NO and CO, researchers have devoted tremendous efforts to the synergistic catalytic NH3-SCR and CO oxidation, and the development of catalyst, which is the crux of catalytic technology, has also become a focus of the relevant research fields. The features of active components are crucial for the preparation of efficient catalyst. Transition metal (such as Cu, Co, Fe, and Ni) oxides have been widely studied for catalytic reactions due to their high activity and low cost, among which CuO is considered as an effective SCR catalyst component, exhibiting distinguished performance within a low temperature range of 250 °C-300 °C [12,13]. However, in actual industrial environments, the composition of sintering flue gas is quite complicated. In addition to the two aforementioned gaseous pollutants, heavy metals are always present as well. Lead (Pb), as one of the heavy metals, is found in relatively high concentrations in coal-fired flue gas and can deposit on the catalyst surface to severely damage its structure. Additionally, Pb can also combine with acidic species, thereby reducing the adsorption sites for NH3, disrupting the surface acidity and redox characteristics of the catalyst and hindering the activation of reactants. Ultimately, the deposit of Pb can lead to decreased catalyst activity and shortened service life, which severely impacts the practical application of the catalyst [14–17]. Previous studies have shown that Pb poisoning could lead to the aggregation of Cu species and occupy active sites to affect the catalyst redox performance, thereby hindering the redox cycle on the catalyst surface [18]. Since the Cu-based catalyst is susceptible to the poisoning effects of Pb in flue gas, enhancing the resistance to Pb poisoning has become a research direction worthy of attention. Suitable auxiliary doping is feasible for enhancing the catalyst resistance to Pb poisoning. Existing studies have attempted to dope catalyst with Fe oxides to enhance their resistance to Pb poisoning. Zhang et al. have developed a MnO x -CeO2/Ti catalyst and found that doping with FeO x could promote the catalyst's resistance to Pb poisoning. The incorporation of FeO x could augment the quantity of active acidic sites, thereby improving the catalyst's ability to adsorb ammonia. The increased adsorption of ammonia enhances the acidity of the catalyst surface while also facilitating the capture of gaseous reactants NO and CO. This, in turn, improves the efficiency of the NH3-SCR reaction and CO oxidation [14]. Moreover, the electron transfer between Fe species and Mn species increased the content of Mn4+, which improved the activity and redox capability of the adsorbed ammonia species. For the Sm-Fe-Mn-Ce/AC catalyst, following Pb poisoning, the inclusion of Fe contributed to the preservation of redox functionality and surface acidity, facilitating the activation of NH3 and consequently enhancing the catalytic performance of the Pb-contaminated catalyst [15]. As for a Fe-Ti-MMT montmorillonite catalyst, the increase of Fe2+ was also reported to improve the quantity of active acidic sites, improving NH3 uptake and redox activity, thereby demonstrating excellent resistance to K and Pb [19]. These findings all indicated that the doping of Fe in catalysts showed certain potential for resisting Pb poisoning. However, little research has been reported to focus on doping Fe as an additive into Cu-based catalyst for enhancing resistance to Pb, and it still remains uncertain whether such catalysts have excellent tolerance to the severe poisoning effect of Pb. In summary, Fe can increase the number of acidic sites and NH3 trapping capacity, resulting in catalyst with stronger Pb resistance. Therefore, Fe-doped Cu-based catalyst appear to have potential to achieve this goal. In light of the above analysis, this paper attempted to dope Cu-based catalyst with Fe, using common titanium dioxide (TiO2) as the support. A supported Cu-Fe catalyst was prepared via a simple impregnation method, aiming for high resistance to Pb poisoning in the cooperative elimination of NO and CO. In this study, Cu/TiO2, Fe/TiO2, Cu-Fe/TiO2, and their respective Pb-loaded catalysts were prepared. The performance of each catalyst in synergistically catalyzing NH3-SCR and CO oxidation was compared through activity tests, and the impact of Pb poisoning on catalyst activity was analyzed. In addition, various characterization techniques were employed to investigate the physicochemical characteristics of the catalyst. A comprehensive analysis of the characterization results was conducted, and possible reaction mechanisms were proposed. This research provides insights into the development of Pb-resistant catalyst applicable to the cooperative interactions between NH3-SCR and CO oxidation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation This study prepared Cu and Fe bimetallic doped catalysts supported on TiO2 and their Pb-poisoned catalysts using an equal volume impregnation method. The details of the above preparation process can be found in the Supporting Information. 2.2 Assessments of catalyst efficacy The schematic diagram of the catalytic activity testing experimental setup is shown in Fig. 1 . The specific content and experimental conditions of the activity test were detailed in the Supporting Information. The conversion ratios of NO and CO and the selectivity of N2 were calculated using the following formulas: (1) N O c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = [ N O ] i n − [ N O ] o u t [ N O ] i n × 100 % (2) C O c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = [ C O ] i n − [ C O ] o u t [ C O ] i n × 100 % (3) N 2 s e l e c t i v i t y [ % ] = ( 1 − 2 [ N 2 O ] o u t [ N O ] i n − [ N O ] o u t ) × 100 % The inlet concentrations of NO and CO are denoted as [NO]in and [CO]in, respectively, while the outlet concentrations of NO, CO, and N2O are represented as [NO] out , [CO] out , and [N2O] out , respectively. 2.3 Analysis of the catalyst Various characterization techniques were employed to examine the physical and chemical properties of the catalysts. The details of the characterization were shown in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst performance To investigate the anti-Pb performance of Fe-modified catalyst in the simultaneous removal of NO and CO, activity tests were conducted on Cu/TiO2, Fe/TiO2, Cu-Fe/TiO2, and their respective PbO-loaded catalysts, as shown in Fig. 2 . The Cu/TiO2 catalyst had a relatively low NO conversion, peaking at no more than 60 %. However, after doping with Fe, the denitration efficiency of the catalyst significantly improved, reaching nearly 86 % NO conversion at 300 °C. Notably, after loading with PbO, the Cu-Fe/TiO2 catalyst did not exhibit a significant drop in denitration efficiency; instead, it showed an increase in efficiency within the 200–300 °C range, even reached a maximum of 91.2 % at 275 °C, with a slight decrease between 300 and 350 °C. This phenomenon was also observed in unmodified Cu/TiO2 and Cu-Pb/TiO2 catalysts. In terms of CO transformation rate, the Fe-modified Cu-Fe/TiO2 catalyst also showed a significant increase in efficiency compared to Cu/TiO2, with a CO transformation rate of more than 98 % at temperatures over 300 °C. The Cu-Fe/TiO2 catalyst loaded with PbO also exhibited an increase in CO conversion ratios, reaching an efficiency of 99 % at 275 °C and continuing to rise at higher temperatures. Furthermore, the NO and CO convertibility of the Cu-Fe-Pb/TiO2 catalyst were much higher than those of the solely loaded Fe/TiO2 and Fe-Pb/TiO2 catalysts. The analysis above indicated that the Fe-enhanced Cu/TiO2 catalyst significantly improved the collaborative removal efficiency of NO and CO, while also demonstrated remarkable resistance to Pb poisoning. Based on the observed increase in NO and CO conversion ratios for the Pb-containing catalyst, it can be speculated that Pb may interact with Cu and Fe oxides, thereby promoting the NH3-SCR and CO oxidation reactions. The investigation results of the N2 selectivity and the content of the byproduct N2O for each catalyst were presented in Fig. S1. In Fig. S1 (a), the pattern of N2 selectivity for Cu-Fe/TiO2 closely resembled that of the unaltered Cu/TiO2 catalyst; although it gradually decreased with increasing temperature, it remains above 83 %. After loading with Pb, the N2 selectivity of the Cu-Fe/TiO2 catalyst showed a slight increase across the entire temperature range. Fig. S1 (b) shows that the N2O levels in the Cu-Fe-Pb/TiO2 catalyst were lower compared to those in the Cu-Fe/TiO2 catalyst, indicating that Pb poisoning actually inhibited the formation of N2O, which was consistent with the observed increase in N2 selectivity. Therefore, the Pb-poisoned Cu-Fe/TiO2 catalyst not only retained outstanding cooperative elimination efficiency for NO and CO but also maintained high N2 selectivity, which had significant practical implications for the removal of pollutants from industrial flue gas. 3.2 Examination of catalyst characterization results 3.2.1 Characteristics of catalyst architecture In order to explore the pore characteristics of the catalyst, N2 adsorption and desorption tests were conducted. Fig. 3 illustrates the acquired N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms along with the pore size distribution profiles, respectively. In Fig. 3(a), all the catalysts exhibited type IV isotherms and H3 hysteresis loops when p/p0 exceeded 0.8, indicating the presence of a mesoporous architecture within the samples [23–25]. It can be seen from Fig. 3(b) that the pore dimensions of the catalyst primarily fell within the range of 10–40 nm. Table S1 lists the detailed information of the porosity characteristics of each catalyst. The specific surface area of the Cu-Fe/TiO2 catalyst was notably higher than that of the Cu/TiO2 catalyst, and it had larger total pore capacity and reduced average pore dimensions, indicating that there was interplay among Cu and Fe oxides, which augmented the surface roughness and produced smaller pore structures. These changes were conducive to the contact of the reaction gas with the active components and additives on the catalyst surface, thereby promoting the function of the catalyst in the catalytic process. After Pb poisoning, the specific surface area of Cu-Fe-Pb/TiO2 catalyst continued to increase. Although the total pore volume did not expand, the average pore size decreased significantly, and the pore structure was further miniaturized. The pore structure of Cu-Fe/TiO2 catalyst was not adversely affected after Pb poisoning. On the contrary, the presence of Pb optimized the surface porosity configuration to a certain extent. Therefore, it was reasonable to further speculate that Pb interacted with Cu and Fe oxides present on the catalyst's surface. The surface microstructure and species dispersion of the catalyst were analyzed by observing transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) images, as shown in Fig. 4 . SEM images revealed that the surface of all samples was in the form of block particles, and the particles upon the surface of Cu/TiO2 and Fe/TiO2 catalysts were dispersed. After Pb poisoning, Cu/TiO2 maintained a relatively dispersed morphology, while Fe/TiO2 catalyst showed particle aggregation, which hindered the reaction, which was consistent with the denitrification efficiency of the two catalysts. The surface particulates of the Cu/TiO2 catalyst modified by Fe were more dispersed, and the surface of Cu-Fe-Pb/TiO2 catalyst was similar to that of Cu-Fe/TiO2 catalyst, which indicated that there may be interaction among Cu and Fe oxides, and Pb did not interfere this interaction and cover the surface to form clusters. In the TEM images, Cu-containing catalyst showed lattice edges of about 0.3524 nm and 0.2530 nm, which were ascribed to the crystal framework distance of TiO2 (101) and CuO (002) crystal facets, separately [9,20,26]. The lattice fringes of 0.2702 nm in the Fe-containing catalyst aligned with the lattice distance of Fe2O3 (104) [27,28]. The above analysis showed that some active species mainly coexisted on the surface of TiO2 in the form of CuO and Fe2O3 after Fe doping and Pb poisoning. Another group of TEM images (100 nm) in Fig. S2 also showed that Cu-Fe/TiO2 and Cu-Fe-Pb/TiO2 catalysts did not show serious crystal overlap and aggregation, which aligned with the SEM results. In the EDS images, Cu and Fe upon the surface of Cu-Fe/TiO2 and Cu-Fe-Pb/TiO2 catalysts were uniformly dispersed on TiO2, which again suggested that the interplay among Cu and Fe oxides promoted their good dispersion, and Pb poisoning did not affect the distribution of various species, which was also one of the important physical factors that the catalyst activity remained good after poisoning. To determine the crystal structure of the sample, powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed, with the results presented in Fig. 5 . Therefore, the XRD diffraction peaks of the samples all showed the characteristics of anatase TiO2, indicating that TiO2 in these samples had a relatively stable crystal structure [20–22]. In comparison to the Cu/TiO2 catalyst, the TiO2 peaks of Cu-Fe/TiO2 catalyst and Cu-Fe-Pb/TiO2 catalyst did not change significantly, which indicated that the doping of Fe did not affect the structure of the support, and the modified catalyst could still maintain the original anatase TiO2 structure after Pb poisoning. Favorable carrier structure was conducive to the effective loading of active components and additives [53,55,56], which provided favorable physical conditions for Cu-Fe-Pb/TiO2 catalyst to maintain good activity. 3.2.2 The oxidation–reduction behavior of the catalyst The existence form of each species on the catalyst was studied by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and the analysis results were shown in Fig. 6 . In Fig. 6(a), the Cu 2p spectrum exhibited two peaks at 932.7 eV and 952.6 eV, corresponding to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2, consequently [29,30]. Two peaks at 932.5 eV and 934.4 eV could be obtained after fitting and deconvolution of Cu 2p3/2 spin-orbit peaks, which correspond to Cu+ and Cu2+, respectively [31–33]. In Fig. 6(b), the peaks at 711.4 eV and 724.8 eV assigned to Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2, respectively [30]. The peak of Fe 2p3/2 could be modeled as the peaks of Fe2+ at 710.7 eV and Fe3+ at 712.6 eV [23,34]. Fig. 6(c) shows that the O 1 s spectra of all catalysts could be resolved into two distinct peaks. The peak at a binding energy of 529.9 eV was attributed to lattice oxygen (Oα), whereas the peak at 531.6 eV was linked to surface-adsorbed oxygen (Oβ) [33,35]. The data of the relative content of the corresponding species in the XPS spectra were listed in Table S2. In comparison to fresh Cu/TiO2 and poisoned Cu-Pb/TiO2, the Cu+/(Cu++Cu2+) ratio of Cu-Fe/TiO2 catalyst increased from 53.38 % and 54.88 % to 55.82 %. The proportion of Cu+ in Pb poisoned catalyst Cu-Fe-Pb/TiO2 increased sharply to 73.08 %. For Fe3+/(Fe3++Fe2+), the Cu-Fe/TiO2 catalyst increased from 53.82 % of Fe/TiO2 and 50.77 % of Fe-Pb/TiO2 to 56.89 %, while the relative proportion of Fe3+ in Cu-Fe-Pb/TiO2 continued to increase to 59.30 % after Pb poisoning. The above data indicated that the incorporation of Fe into the Cu/TiO2 catalyst promoted the formation of low-valent Cu species. This was because the interplay among Fe and Cu species changed the charge environment, and Cu had higher electronegativity and stronger ability to capture electrons. Therefore, Cu2+ was converted into Cu+ [23,24]. In addition, Cu+ can be used as the adsorption site of CO, and more CO was adsorbed and activated by Cu+ with higher relative content, thus promoting the CO oxidation reaction [23]. The introduction of Fe3+ species enhanced the catalyst's performance in two ways. First, it promoted the formation of oxygen vacancies within the catalyst, thereby improving its redox properties. Second, the redox cycle between Cu+/Cu2+ and Fe2+/Fe3+ facilitated electron transfer between Cu and Fe ions, further boosting the catalytic activity [23,35]. After Pb poisoning, the rates of Cu+/(Cu++Cu2+) and Fe3+/(Fe3++Fe2+) of Cu-Fe/TiO2 catalysts were markedly increased, indicating that Pb participated in the interplay among Cu and Fe species, promoted electron transfer and the reaction. In addition, the Oβ/(Oβ+Oα) rates of Cu-Fe/TiO2 and Cu-Fe-Pb/TiO2 also increased from 26.37 % of Cu/TiO2 to 27.83 % and 29.00 %, respectively. The surface chemisorbed oxygen Oβ had a high mobility, usually with high activity and strong oxidation ability [30,33]. The Fe modification aided the generation of more chemically adsorbed oxygen and the Oβ of the catalyst was further improved following Pb contamination, which facilitated improved electron transfer between Oβ and the active component, and also promoted the ability to oxidize NO to NO2, thereby advancing the “fast SCR” reaction [13,14,36]. Consequently, the Cu-Fe/TiO2 catalyst exhibited high cooperative catalytic NH3-SCR and CO oxidation activity along with excellent resistance to Pb poisoning. The increase in the proportions of Cu+, Fe3+, and Oβ also elucidated why Pb species, originally considered a poison, can instead enhance catalytic activity. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) can be used to explore the redox characteristics of the catalyst, and the TPR spectra of each sample were shown in Fig. 7 . The reduction peaks of Cu/TiO2 and Cu-Pb/TiO2 at about 195 °C corresponded to Cu+→Cu0, while the peak at 460 °C was attributed to Cu2+→Cu+ [13,24,33]. There was a reduction peak at 450 °C for Fe/TiO2 and Fe-Pb/TiO2, corresponding to the reduction of Fe2O3→Fe3O4 [16,37]. After Fe doping, the Cu-Fe/TiO2 catalyst also had a Cu+→Cu0 peak at low temperature, while the broad peak among 400–500 °C was the result of the overlap of Cu2+→Cu+ and Fe2O3→Fe3O4. Moreover, three additional reduction peaks appeared, a Cu+ reduction peak at about 230 °C, a Fe2O3→Fe3O4 peak at 340 °C, and a Fe3O4→FeO reduction peak at 550 °C [23,38,39]. The appearance of new peaks indicated that the redox activity of the catalyst was improved, which was as a result of the interplay among Cu and Fe oxides. The H2-TPR curve of Cu-Fe-Pb/TiO2 was similar to that of Cu-Fe/TiO2 catalyst, and the intensity of reduction peak of Cu+ at lower temperatures and Fe2O3→Fe3O4 reduction peak at 340 °C was slightly enhanced, indicating that the redox efficiency of the catalyst after Pb poisoned was even stronger, which was closely related to the participation of Pb species and the improvement of electron transfer between species. The existence of oxygen species upon the catalyst surface was analyzed by O2 temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD) test, and the diagram is presented in Fig. 7(b). The plots of all samples could be categorized into two primary peaks. The peak observed below 450 °C corresponded to the signal of oxygen that was chemically attached to the surface, while the peak above 600 °C was associated with lattice oxygen species [40–42]. It was generally believed that chemisorbed oxygen was related to the generation of oxygen vacancies, and the former was also an important participant in the redox reaction process [11,35,43]. Compared with Cu/TiO2 and Cu-Pb/TiO2, the first peak of Cu-Fe/TiO2 and Cu-Fe-Pb/TiO2 was enhanced, and the second peak intensity was weakened. It was speculated that Fe modification promoted the lattice oxygen of the catalyst to convert to chemisorbed oxygen, thereby promoting the reaction. It was also confirmed that the interplay among Cu and Fe oxides was the key factor to produce more active species [12,23,54]. Furthermore, to explore the concentration of surface oxygen vacancies in the catalyst, the electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrum was tested, and the signal curve was shown in Fig. S3. All catalysts showed obvious symmetrical signals at about g = 2.003, corresponding to the oxygen vacancy intensity of each catalyst. Oxygen vacancies could promote the dissociation of NO bonds, which in turn could promote the reduction of NO [44,45]. The signal from the Cu-Fe/TiO2 catalyst was greater than that of the singly doped metal oxide and the corresponding Pb-poisoned catalyst, this suggested that the incorporation of Fe facilitated the development of lattice defects, so the concentration of oxygen vacancies was improved, which also proved the positive effect of Cu-Fe interaction on the reaction [33]. In comparison to Cu-Fe/TiO2, the signal intensity of Cu-Fe-Pb/TiO2 was stronger, indicating a higher oxygen vacancy concentration than the fresh modified catalyst, which meant that Pb poisoning did not hinder the synergy between the original species, but assisted the activation and migration of oxygen species [46]. This observation may also be related to the fact that the activity of Cu-Fe-Pb/TiO2 surpassed that of Cu-Fe/TiO2 during the activity assessment. 3.2.3 Surface protonation characteristics and adsorption capabilities of the catalyst The surface acidity levels of the catalyst were investigated using NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), as illustrated in Fig. 8 (a). The broad peaks of all catalysts in the range of 200–500 °C corresponded to the overlap of NH3 desorption peaks were observed at sites with weak and medium-strength acidity [47,48]. There was another peak between 500 and 600 °C for the Cu-containing catalyst, which was the desorption peak of NH3 at the strong acid site [47]. Compared with Cu/TiO2, Cu-Pb/TiO2 and modified Cu-Fe/TiO2, the peak intensity of Cu-Fe-Pb/TiO2 was significantly enhanced and shifted towards lower temperatures, indicating that the Fe modified catalyst after Pb poisoning even had stronger surface acidity. This was because the doping of iron oxide optimized the surface structure of the catalyst and ensured sufficient acidic sites, while the Pb species on surface further modified the electron density around Cu and Fe, accelerating electron transfer and promoting the formation of additional active sites [14]. Therefore, Fe modification improved the adsorption capacity of the catalyst for NH3, which in turn promoted the progress of NH3-SCR, which was also one of the powerful guarantees for the catalyst to have Pb resistance. The uptake of NO on the catalyst surface was studied by NO temperature-programmed desorption (NO-TPD) spectra, and the results were presented in Fig. 8(b). The spectrum of the catalyst could be roughly divided into three peaks, labeled as 'a', 'b' and 'c', respectively. The 'a' peak at about 83 °C corresponded to the physical uptake of NO [30,49]. The peak intensity of Cu-Fe/TiO2 and Cu-Fe-Pb/TiO2 was enhanced, indicating that Fe modification could promote the adsorption of NO at lower temperatures, which was related to the interplay among Cu and Fe species. In addition, Fe oxides changed the original electron density, promoted the formation of a greater number of unpaired electrons, weakened the N − O bond, and contributed to the dissociation of adsorbed NO [23,50]. The 'b' peak in the range of 200–350 °C was ascribed to the breakdown of monodentate nitrate [30]. The 'c' peak observed above 350 °C was associated with the various decomposition processes of nitrite, bidentate nitrate, and bridging nitrate compounds [23,50,51]. In contrast to Cu-Fe/TiO2, the 'b' and 'c' peaks of Cu-Fe-Pb/TiO2 had no obvious signs of weakening, indicating that Pb poisoning would not adversely affect the decomposition of nitrite and various nitrate species. The effective decomposition of these intermediates also ensured the smooth progress of the reaction. The adsorption of CO was shown in the CO temperature-programmed desorption (CO-TPD) map, as shown in Fig. 8(c). There were three peaks in the spectra of all Cu-containing catalysts, which were recorded as 'α', 'β' and 'γ' from low to high temperature. The 'α' peak between 50 and 200 °C indicated CO desorption at Cu0 and Cu+ sites [36,52]. The 'β' peak at 300–500 °C was related to the uptake of CO on the support. Fe/TiO2 and Fe-Pb/TiO2 only had this CO adsorption peak, indicating that their adsorption capacity for CO was immensely weak, which led to their extremely weak oxidation of CO [52]. The 'γ' peak was located above 550 °C, which was related to the strong chemical adsorption of CO and could be attributed to the decomposition of bidentate carbonates [35]. Such adsorbed intermediate species were not easily present in excess; otherwise, they may hinder the reactants from reacting on the catalyst surface due to the accumulation of carbonate and other species [51]. Cu-Fe-Pb/TiO2 not only ensured the adsorption of CO at the active site at low temperatures, but also did not appear the excessive accumulation of intermediate species represented by the 'γ' peak. Therefore, Fe modification helped to improve the resistance to Pb in the CO oxidation reaction. 3.3 The reaction mechanism of catalyst resistance to Pb poisoning Based on the above characterization analysis, the anti-Pb poisoning reaction mechanism of Fe altered Cu/TiO2 catalyst synergistically catalyzing NH3-SCR and CO oxidation was speculated, as shown in Scheme 1 . As shown in the scheme, the structure of the catalyst support was retained after modification, and the active components and additives were effectively dispersed on TiO2, exhibiting no obvious agglomeration or aggregation. Moreover, there was a strong synergistic interaction among Fe and Cu species, which facilitated electron transfer, generated more Cu+ and Fe3+ that were beneficial to the reaction, and enhanced the redox ability. The increase of chemisorbed oxygen was also a favorable factor to improve the catalytic performance. In particular, oxygen vacancies provided convenience for the cycle of reactions between active species and the dissociation of N − O. Another important factor was that the modified catalyst maintained excellent adsorption performance, even after Pb poisoning. An unexpected but beneficial fact was that after Pb poisoning, the Pb species drive the CO and NO removals reactions, acted as a promoting factor. This phenomenon was attributed to the collaborative effect among Pb species and Cu, Fe species, which facilitated the reaction. Therefore, Fe modification helped the Cu/TiO2 catalyst to have excellent resistance to Pb poisoning. 4 Conclusions In this study, a Fe-modified Cu-based catalyst was developed and its distinguished collaborative catalytic NH3-SCR and CO oxidation ability was observed along with an excellent anti-Pb poisoning performance. The activity test results showed that Cu-Fe-Pb/TiO2 could achieve 91.2 % NO conversion and 99 % CO conversion at 275 °C. The physical and chemical properties of the catalysts were examined utilizing a range of characterization methods. After Fe doping, the TiO2 as the carrier could maintain the pristine crystal structure, and the active component Cu oxide and the auxiliary Fe oxide could be well dispersed on the surface of the carrier. The strong interaction among Cu and Fe oxides facilitated the increase of Cu+ and Fe3+ concentrations and improved the redox properties of the catalyst. In addition, this synergistic effect also increased the chemisorbed oxygen, and especially the higher concentration of surface oxygen vacancies greatly enhanced the promotion of the reaction. The modified catalyst retained sufficient surface acidity and gas adsorption capacity after Pb poisoning. This research offers a foundation for the advancement of catalysts designed to combat heavy metal poisoning, enhancing the concurrent elimination of nitrogen oxides (NO) and carbon monoxide (CO) from industrial exhaust emissions. coredata.dc:description: Nitrogen oxides (NO x ) and carbon monoxide (CO) are two major pollutants in industrial flue gas. Currently, ammonia selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) and CO oxidation catalysts are susceptible to heavy metal impurities such as Pb, which leads to a reduction in catalytic activities. In this study, an excellent anti-Pb poisoning Fe-enhanced Cu/TiO2 catalyst was prepared for the synergistic control of NO and CO with maximum 91.2 % and 99 % conversion ratios at 275 °C. The active components of the modified catalyst were well dispersed on the TiO2. The doping of Fe alleviated the surface aggregation caused by Pb, while the pore size was decreased and the specific surface area was increased. Synergistic interaction between Cu and Fe produced more variable valence states, leading to highly active chemisorbed oxygen and oxygen vacancies, which were beneficial for the NO and CO removal. Furthermore, after Fe loading more acidic sites were retained on the catalyst surface, which improved the oxidation–reduction characteristics of the catalyst. This research presents a viable approach for designing efficient catalyst for the concurrent removal of NO and CO from industrial emissions while demonstrating great resistance to Pb-poisoning.
